articles.headline: Debt Plan Is Delayed in Europe
articles.snippet: European leaders will examine proposals this weekend, but no decisions will be made until a summit next week.
articles.abstract: European leaders will examine proposals this weekend, but no decisions will be made until a summit next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The grand plan is on pause.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Stephen Castle and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Audit Flaws Revealed, at Long Last
articles.snippet: An oversight agency identified problems in Deloitte & Touche audits in 2007, but because of confidentiality requirements, the failings didn’t become public until 41 months later.
articles.abstract: An oversight agency identified problems in Deloitte & Touche audits in 2007, but because of confidentiality requirements, the failings didn’t become public until 41 months later.
articles.lead_paragraph: With hindsight, we now know that auditors in 2007 should have been looking carefully at bank books.

articles.headline: Stealing the Show
articles.snippet: This season, gallery shows, like the exhibition at the Gagosian Gallery chronicling Picasso’s love affair with the painter Françoise Gilot are generating the most buzz.
articles.abstract: This season, gallery shows, like the exhibition at the Gagosian Gallery chronicling Picasso’s love affair with the painter Françoise Gilot are generating the most buzz.
articles.lead_paragraph: She’s almost 90 and still living very much in the present, quietly painting every day in her West Side studio. Yet Françoise Gilot — Picasso’s muse and lover and the mother of two of his children — is about to revisit her past.

articles.headline: Negative Exposure for Kodak
articles.snippet: The company, suffering from the decline of film photography, is pressing an inkjet printer line that risks being a lurch “from one buggy whip business to another.”
articles.abstract: The company, suffering from the decline of film photography, is pressing an inkjet printer line that risks being a lurch “from one buggy whip business to another.”
articles.lead_paragraph: At least Eastman Kodak didn’t pin its latest turnaround effort on the fax machine. Just the same, as one securities analyst said, Wall Street worries that the once pre-eminent film company is jumping “from one buggy whip business to another.”

articles.headline: Jobs Tried Exotic Treatments to Combat Cancer, Book Says
articles.snippet: A 630-page biography on Steve Jobs also includes previously unknown details about his romantic life, his marriage, his relationship with his sister and his business dealings.
articles.abstract: A 630-page biography on Steve Jobs also includes previously unknown details about his romantic life, his marriage, his relationship with his sister and his business dealings.
articles.lead_paragraph: In his last years, Steven P. Jobs veered from exotic diets to cutting-edge treatments as he fought the cancer that ultimately took his life, according to a new biography to be published on Monday.

articles.headline: Hip Surgery Option Loses Key Backer
articles.snippet: The California Technology Assessment Forum reversed its stance on a technique known as hip resurfacing, citing insufficient evidence regarding the surgery’s safety and efficacy.
articles.abstract: The California Technology Assessment Forum reversed its stance on a technique known as hip resurfacing, citing insufficient evidence regarding the surgery’s safety and efficacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: In another controversy involving all-metal hips, an influential group has found that there is insufficient evidence to show that an alternative technique known as hip resurfacing is as safe and effective as a traditional replacement.

articles.headline: Irate News Corp. Shareholders to Take Murdoch to the Woodshed
articles.snippet: A shareholders meeting on Friday in Los Angeles is expected to be heated, with investors demanding accountability after a phone-hacking scandal deeply embarrassed the company.
articles.abstract: A shareholders meeting on Friday in Los Angeles is expected to be heated, with investors demanding accountability after a phone-hacking scandal deeply embarrassed the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The annual News Corporation shareholders meeting has always been a raucous and unpredictable event.

articles.headline: Qaddafi’s Death Places Focus on Arab Spring’s ‘Hard Road’
articles.snippet: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s capture captivated the Arab world, but images of his bloody corpse were a reminder of the Arab Spring’s many still-unresolved conflicts.
articles.abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s capture captivated the Arab world, but images of his bloody corpse were a reminder of the Arab Spring’s many still-unresolved conflicts.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Like the flight of Tunisia’s dictator or the trial of Egypt’s, the capture of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Thursday afternoon captivated the Arab world, giving a renewed sense of power and possibility. But the photographs of his bloody corpse that circulated just moments later on cellphones and television screens quickly tempered that exhilaration with a reminder of the many still-unresolved conflicts that the Arab Spring has also unleashed.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Cuts Some Health Care Benefits
articles.snippet: Citing rising costs, Wal-Mart is substantially rolling back coverage for part-time workers and significantly raising premiums for many full-time staff.
articles.abstract: Citing rising costs, Wal-Mart is substantially rolling back coverage for part-time workers and significantly raising premiums for many full-time staff.
articles.lead_paragraph: After trying to mollify its critics in recent years by offering better health care benefits to its employees, Wal-Mart is substantially rolling back coverage for part-time workers and significantly raising premiums for many full-time staff.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: After Making Capture in Pipe, Displaying the Trophies of War
articles.snippet: Fighters from Misurata were the first to find Colonel Qaddafi and kept as souvenirs his last prized possessions.
articles.abstract: Fighters from Misurata were the first to find Colonel Qaddafi and kept as souvenirs his last prized possessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISURATA, Libya — They had the ultimate trophies of the revolution: the colonel’s golden gun, his satellite phone, his brown scarf and one black boot.
